**Asia Monday Morning Espresso - July-Sep 2024 redux?**
Chetan Seth, CFA - NSL / Ankit Yadav - NSFSPL

**All eyes on the US NFP report. Another weak report the coming week could dent risk-appetite, in our view** US NFP report to be main focus for markets coming week. With NVDA results out of the way and in-line US Core PCE on Friday,all eyes will be on US' August NFP report in the coming week. July's NFP report was clearly weak and another weak report will likely provide fodder to macro-bears, in our view. Nomura's US economists expect +85K headline gains (vs consensus' 75K) and the unemployment rate (UE) at 4.3% (in line with consensus), which we think should not unnerve equity investors. However,in a scenario, where the NFP report is clearly weaker (
BYD (1211 HK) (Buy) - Bottomed out in 2Q25: likely turnaround in 2026F (TP HKD 163.67- - HKD 132.00)
Joel Ying, CFA - NIHK / Ethan Zhang - NIHK

Maintain Buy; TP cut to HKD132, implying \(15\%\) upside; still sustainable long- term growth outlook, with likely turnaround in 2026F. Considering the intensifying competition, the government's anti- involution stance and also its own strategy for 2025, BYD's 2Q25 results came in below market expectations. With no more material strategy changes likely this year, we expect BYD to focus more on its 2026E key strategy. With the lessons learned in 2025, so far, we believe BYD will be well- prepared. For FY25- 27F, we lower our shipment forecasts by \(10 - 11\%\) and top line forecasts by \(9\%\) each, while also revising down our GPM/OPM forecasts by \(2\%\) for each year, to reflect the China auto market's latest situation. As a result, our FY25- 27F earnings are \(27 - 30\%\) below our previous estimates. We now forecast BYD to achieve \(15\% /18\%\) revenue/earnings CAGR's over FY24- 27F. We cut our SOTP- based TP to HKD132 (from HKD163.67), while reaffirming our Buy rating.
BYD (002594 CH) (Buy) - Bottomed out in 2Q25: likely turnaround in 2026F (TP CNY 167.66- - CNY 133.00)
Joel Ying, CFA - NIHK / Ethan Zhang - NIHK

Maintain Buy; TP cut to CNY133, implying \(16\%\) upside; still sustainable long- term growth outlook, with likely turnaround in 2026F. Considering the intensifying competition, the government's anti- involution stance and also its own strategy for 2025, BYD's 2Q25 results came in below market expectations. With no more material strategy changes likely this year, we expect BYD to focus more on its 2026E key strategy. With the lessons learned in 2025, so far, we believe BYD will be well- prepared. For FY25- 27F, we lower our shipment forecasts by \(10 - 11\%\) and top line forecasts by \(9\%\) each, while also revising down our GPM/OPM forecasts by \(2\%\) for each year, to reflect the China auto market's latest situation. As a result, our FY25- 27F earnings are \(27 - 30\%\) below our previous estimates. We now forecast BYD to achieve \(15\% /18\%\) revenue/earnings CAGR's over FY24- 27F. We cut our SOTP- based TP to CNY133 (from CNY167.66), while reaffirming our Buy rating.
Alibaba Group Holding (BABA US) (Buy) - Quick commerce shaping up into a new driver (TP USD 152.00- - USD 170.00) Jialong Shi - NIHK / Rachel Guo - NIHK

Cloud business gaining momentum on robust AI demand; maintain BuyQC brings the much- needed growth, but causes temporary margin pressure. BABA announced that its quick commerce's (QC) daily average order volume reached 80mn in August, vs. our estimated 90mn for Meituan's (MT; 3690 HK, Buy). This is a temporary win for BABA given that its scale (in terms of order volume) used to be merely \(\sim 40\%\) of MT's. BABA has already seen some benefits from its QC investment. BABA views QC as a new growth driver in its own right, as well as a driver to the entire ecosystem. QC has contributed to solid \(25\%\) y- y growth of monthly active buyers on its flagship Taobao app in the first three weeks of August, according to BABA, which in turn lends support to the growth of its CMR (customer management revenue) and potential savings on the marketing dollars. As a result, BABA predicts its CMR to maintain a similar growth rate in the near term as the \(10\%\) y- y growth registered in the June quarter.
Raghavendra Divekar, CFA - NSM / Kriti Agrawal - NSFSPL

We expect CPO prices to remain stable at MYR4,375/MT until 4 September.CPO (crude palm oil) spot prices declined \(1\%\) w- w to MYR4,370/MT in the week ended 28 August 2025, according to the Malaysia Palm Oil Board (MPOB). This was largely due to lower prices of soybean oil due to concerns over demand in the US. For the next week, we expect prices to remain stable as rising exports are balanced by weaker soybean oil prices. Overall, we expect the average CPO price to remain at MYR4,375/MT until 4 September. However, if exports from Malaysia rise sharply or if production concerns rise, CPO prices could increase to MYR4,450/MT. US EPA approves biofuel waivers for small refiners, stirring concerns over demand. According to a 23 August article in Reuters (link), the US EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) has approved most of its backlog of waivers by small oil refiners, leading to concerns over biofuel demand.
Jeong Woo Park - NSL

IP growth slowed to \(0.3\%\) m- o- m, sa in July from \(1.7\%\) in June (Consensus: \(0.2\%\) ; Nomura: \(1.9\%\) ), owing to weaker production in chips \((- 3.6\%)\) and auto vehicles & parts \((- 7.3\%)\) , offsetting strong production in electronic parts \((20.9\%)\) . However, year- on- year growth in IP picked up sharply \(5.0\%\) in July from \(1.6\%\) in June, suggesting underlying growth trends have held up relatively well. Reflecting weaker activity in the manufacturing and services sectors, all industry production growth also slowed. Domestic demand picked up, with retail sales and business facility investment growth increasing and offsetting weaker construction activity. Key activity directly related to service consumption also picked up, though headline growth in service production slowed due to weaker activity in the finance sector. Nomura- KRnow is tracking Q3 GDP growth at \(1.1\%\) q- o- q, sa (our base case forecast: \(1.1\%\) ), up from \(0.6\%\) in Q2, indicating a strong recovery ahead.
First Insights - Indonesia: Protests return
Euben Paracuelles - NSL / Nabila Amani - NSL / Craig Chan - NSL / Wee Choon Teo - NSL / Vicky Chen - NSL / Manthan Shingala - NSL

A series of protests hit Jakarta and some of them turned mobelt with tragically, one reported casualty. We believe the likelihood of more protests in the near- term is high. So far, we see limited concrete steps from the government to appease protesters at a time when economic conditions are weak and household sentiment is fllile. We see the risk of more short- run populist measures, a dimming of reform prospects, a possible delay of another 25bp cut expected by Bank Indonesia (BI) in September. FX strategy: We lower the conviction level on short USD/IDR to 5 (from 4) because of the near- term risk that the protests may escalate. However, if the situation eases in the near- term, we believe IDR could reverse some of the relative underperformance. A series of protests led by students and workers This week, a series of protests took place in Jakarta and across the nation.
Hannah Liu - NIHK / Jing Wang - NIHK / Harrington Zhang - NIHK / Ting Lu - NIHK

New home sales volume: CRIC's top 100 developers. According to CRIC, contract sales volume growth for the top 100 developers worsened again, declining to \(- 31.2\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 18.6\%\) in July. In value terms, it improved to \(- 17.6\%\) y- o- y in August from \(- 24.3\%\) in July. The divergence between volume and value terms points to better performance in large cities, driven by easing measures. On 8 August, Beijing relaxed home purchase restrictions by allowing qualified buyers to acquire additional properties in areas beyond the Fifth Ring. Subsequently, on 26 August, Shanghai announced a cut in mortgage rates for second homes and an easing in home buying rules outside the Outer Ring. We expect other tier- 1 cities such as Shenzhen and Guangzhou to implement similar supportive measures.
Hannah Liu - NIHK / Jing Wang - NIHK / Harrington Zhang - NIHK / Ting Lu - NIHK

The official manufacturing PMI remained subdued at 49.4 in August, increasing marginally from 49.3 in July and broadly in line with consensus (Consensus: 49.5; Nomura: 49.3). The non- manufacturing PMI edged up to 50.3 in August from 50.1 in July, slightly above consensus (Consensus: 50.2; Nomura: 50.0). Despite the marginal rise, the manufacturing PMI has remained below 50 for five months since the tariff blitz in April, with persistent weakness in new export orders. Meanwhile, the continued rise in the price indices reflects the intensifying campaign against low- price competition, which could dampen investment and output activity. The improvement in the non- manufacturing PMI was primarily driven by capital market services, buoyed by the recent stock market rally, while retail sales and property sectors have remained a drag. The subdued manufacturing PMI points to continued weak growth momentum on various fronts.
Jeong Woo Park - NSL

The government announced the 2026 budget, with its spending projected to rise by \(8.1\%\) y- o- y, in comparison with the initial 2025 budget (before the extra budgets). However, after including two rounds of extra budgets this year, effective spending growth is slower at \(3.5\%\) y- o- y in 2026. As a result, the managed fiscal deficit is expected to narrow to \(4.0\%\) of GDP in 2026 from \(4.2\%\) (government estimates) in 2025. The government will increase spending on R&D and industry transition over the next four years to restructure the economy, which may help reboot the domestic economy. Spending on health/social welfare and national defense is also likely to increase notably to meet growing structural demand. We expect a positive impact on growth from higher government spending on R&D and industry.
Jing Wang - NIHK / Harrington Zhang - NIHK / Hannah Liu - NIHK / Ting Lu - NIHK

Activity data broadly slowed in July and disappointed markets. Weak growth momentum is likely to be sustained in August, despite the onshore stock market rally. We expect the PMIs to remain low, export and IP growth to moderate, and retail sales growth to remain subdued. Daily average stock trading volume soared to a record high of RMB2.3trn in August, but its positive spillovers to the real economy might be quite limited. Chinese households' assets are still concentrated in property, while the salaries of financial practitioners remain largely capped. The rising growth headwinds call for more policy support, but deploying pro- growth measures might risk causing a stock market bubble. In our view, Beijing's best strategy is to draw lessons from the past, resist the temptation to fuel the stock markets through high- profile monetary measures in the near term, remain vigilant by avoiding contractionary policies, clean up the property mess, and address some deep- rooted problems such as the unequal social security system.
Sonal Varma - NSL / Aurodeep Nandi - NFASL
Strong Q2 GDP is amplified by low deflators, one- off factors and is backward looking. The tariff impact will be visible after September.

Real GDP growth rose sharply above expectations to \(7.8\%\) y- o- y in Q2 from \(7.4\%\) in Q1. In our view, this is not a signal of strong underlying demand, as it was boosted by low deflators, export frontloading, and its composition appears at odds with other high frequency data and demand signals. Growth data appear mixed so far in Q3, but real GDP will get another boost from a low deflator, export frontloading (until August) and base effects, keeping it at an elevated \(7.4\%\) y- o- y. We expect the impact of higher tariffs to be visible after September, leading to a sharper slowdown to \(6.0\%\) in Q4 and \(5.6\%\) in Q1 2026. Our view on the economic

cycle remains unchanged, but given the higher Q2 GDP, we are statistically revising our FY26 GDP growth forecast to \(6.6\%\) (from \(6.0\%\) ). This implies average growth of \(5.8\%\) y- o- y in H2 FY26 versus \(7.6\%\) in H1 FY26.
Euben Paracuelles - NSL / Yiru Chen - NSL

Malaysia: Quarterly approved investments by sector. The Malaysian Investment Development Authority (MIDA) reported that Malaysia attracted MYR100.6bn of approved investments in Q2, up from MYR89.8bn in Q1, despite rising external uncertainty. This brings the H1 total to MYR190.3bn, rising \(18.7\%\) y- o- y, driven by both the services and manufacturing sectors. In particular, foreign investments (56.1% of total approvals) surged \(43.5\%\) y- o- y to MYR106.8bn in H1, led by services (100.7% y- o- y). By state, Johor was the largest driver, attracting MYR56.0bn of approved investments in H1, according to the MIDA, which is more than four times the MYR13bn in H1 2024. This was likely driven by the launch of the JS- SEZ in January, thanks to initiatives to expedite the approval process and incentives to attract investors. This supports our long- held view of sustained investment spending growth, underpinned by the implementation of economic reforms, including recently the 13MP, which would help to counter external risks.
Charnon Boonnuch - NSL / Euben Paracuelles - NSL

The Constitutional Court dismissed PM Paetongtarn on the grounds of violating ethical standards that involved a leaked phone call with Cambodia leader Hun Sen. We believe she will be replaced by Chakasem, who is from the same ruling Pheu Thai (PT) party, suggesting the PT- led coalition government likely remains intact for now. We maintain our cautious GDP growth forecasts of \(1.8\%\) and \(1.6\%\) for 2025 and 2026, respectively, and our fiscal deficit forecasts of \(5.0\%\) and \(4.5\%\) of GDP for FY25- 26. Rising political uncertainty and prolonged growth weakness support our view that a credit rating downgrade by Moody's is likely over the next few quarters. PM Paetongtarn was dismissed by the Constitutional Court. The Constitutional Court today voted 6- 3 to dismiss PM Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 39, over a violation of ethical standards involving a leaked phone call with Cambodia leader Hun Sen (see First Insights - Thailand: The Constitutional Court accepted the petition to remove PM Paetongtarn, 1 July 2025).
Aichi Amemiya - NSI / George Buckley - Nlplc / Ting Lu - NIHK / Kyohei Morita - NSC / Euben Paracuelles - NSL / David Seif - NSI / Rob Subbaraman - NSL / Sonal Varma - NSL

HIGHLIGHTS OF WEEK. China: Will the real economy benefit from the stock market boom? We believe a stock market rally may provide limited boost to the real economy. United States: August Employment Preview. We expect headline NFP likely grew 85k in August. India: US tariffs hit \(50\%\) economic- policy inflection ahead. We expect targeted fiscal support and a 25bp rate cut in October, and have lowered our FY26 GDP growth forecast to \(6\%\) from \(6.2\%\) . Asia: Entering the next leg of policy easing. Amid benign inflation, weaker growth and Fed rate cuts will provide the next trigger. We expect more cuts in India, Korea, Thailand, and Indonesia. Economic Insights - A trio of forces are impacting global trade patterns. Focusing on over 20 of the world's largest economies, the impacts vary. Japan: FY25- 27 economic outlook. We expect: (1) core CPI inflation to swing downward in 2026 and then return to around \(2\%\) in 2027; and (2) BOJ rate hikes to end in 2027.

Jeremy Schwartz - NSI / Ruchir Sharma - NSI / Aichi Amemiya - NSI / David Seif - NSI / Jacklyn Goloborodsky - NSI We expect headline nonfarm payrolls (NFP) likely grew 85k in August. Historical patterns suggest payrolls could be revised higher modestly for July. Private job gains likely remained slow at 80k following a 83k increase in July. Government employment likely rebounded following a negative print in July. We forecast the unemployment rate, which has been emphasized by policymakers as a reliable measure to gauge labor market strength, likely ticked up by one- tenth to \(4.3\%\) in August. Average hourly earnings (AHE) growth likely just rounded down to \(0.3\%\) m- o- m. Risks are skewed towards a higher print due to a positive calendar effect in August. The labor market is losing momentum, and shifting balance of risks to the Fed's dual mandate is likely to lead to a 25bp cut at the September meeting. Contained layoffs and few signs of acute labor market stress are likely to limit aggressive easing though.

David Seif - NSI / Aichi Amemiya - NSI / Jeremy Schwartz - NSI / Ruchir Sharma - NSI / Jacklyn Goloborodsky - NSI President Trump fired Fed governor Lisa Cook while Cook refused to step down, leading to a high stakes legal battle. We expect headline payroll growth remained subdued at 85k in August. Historical patterns suggest the NFP number for July could be revised higher modestly. The unemployment rate likely ticked up by one- tenth to \(4.3\%\) . Core PCE inflation July came close to our expectation at \(0.273\%\) m- o- m, driven by nonmarket- based service components. President Trump fired Governor Cook. Earlier this week, President Trump announced he had fired Fed Governor Lisa Cook on the grounds of mortgage fraud allegations. Cook refused to step down and filed a lawsuit against President Trump.

Action: Maintain Buy and raise TP to CNY80, implying \(16.4\%\) upside. Accelink reported 1H25results on 27 August after market close, with revenue up by \(68.6\%\) y- y, translating to \(66.1\%\) y- y growth in 2Q25 (+35.9% q- q). The 2Q25 revenue growth beat our estimates by \(24\%\) , likely driven by stronger momentum in data center transceivers, in our view. Earnings grew \(78.4\%\) y- y in 1H25 (2Q25: \(69.3\%\) y- y), in line with our estimates. GPM declined 2.2pp y- y in 2Q25, mainly driven by product mix change (more contributions from optical transceivers), but partially offset by its effective expense control (opex down by 0.3pp y- y in 1H25). We raise FY25- 27F revenue forecasts by \(5 - 21\%\) and earnings forecasts by \(4 - 19\%\) to reflect better DC transceiver demand. We maintain our Buy rating and raise TP to CNY80, based on 43x FY26F EPS of CNY1.87 (previously 36x), in line with a FY24- 27F earnings CAGR of \(43\%\) .
Quick Note - Alibaba Group Holding (BABA US) (Buy) - Upbeat tone on ecommerce, quick commerce & Al (TP USD 152.00) Jialong Shi - NIHK / Rachel Guo - NIHK

1QFY26 results: Key highlights from the print call. BABA painted a bullish outlook for its ecommerce, cloud and the new quick commerce business. Quick commerce (QC) is the market focus, in view of the intense competition between BABA and Meituan (3690 HK, Buy) since May 2025, in our view. BABA indicated that its QC daily average order volume reached 80mn in August, with beverage- related orders accounting for less than \(30\%\) of the total. We estimate Meituan's daily average orders in August was over 90mn. Hence, the gap between the two had narrowed significantly in the past three months. BABA conceded its QC was in big loss - in the June quarter, the EBITA of its newly created China ecommerce group (CEG, including Taobao, quick commerce and travel service) dropped \(21\%\) or CNY10bn, which was mainly caused by the QC investment of around CNY11bn in the quarter.
Gree Electric Appliances (000651 CH) (Buy) - Sales and earnings weakened in 2Q25 (TP CNY 54.40- - CNY 52.70) Jizhou Dong, CFA - NIHK / Riley Jin - NIHK

The worst performer among major home appliance names in 1H25; a lack of dividend is also disappointing Both sales and earnings declined y- y in 2Q25. Gree released its 2Q25 results (28 Aug), generally lower than the capital market's expectation, in our view. The company's quarterly revenue decreased \(12.1\%\) y- y (leading to a 1H25 revenue decline of \(2.7\%\) y- y), while quarterly core earnings decreased by a similar \(11.9\%\) y- y to CNY8.2bn (1H25 core earnings up a marginal \(0.6\%\) y- y). Gree continued to experience gross margin pressure in 2Q25 with another 0.6pp y- y decline in the past quarter (after a 1.4pp y- y decline in 1Q25), while the 2Q25 operating margin stayed flat y- y in 2Q25, partially due to the company's efforts to reduce costs/improve efficiency. In addition to the set of weak results (the slowest 2Q25 revenue/earnings growth among the three major home appliance names we cover), unlike most of its peers, Gree also did not declare any interim dividend, which could be perceived as another negative catalyst to Gree's share price, in our view.
Haier Smart Home - A (600690 CH) (Buy) - Steady performance: interim dividend for first time (TP CNY 37.60) Jizhou Dong, CFA - NIHK / Riley Jin - NIHK
Sales/earnings growth on track; increased shareholder returns a plus; maintain Buy

2Q25 results sold; more attention to shareholder returns another positive. Haier announced its 2Q25 results (28 Aug) with solid readings from all major perspectives, in our view. Quarterly revenue increased \(10.4\%\) y- y to CNY77bn (1H24 revenue growth of \(10.2\%\) y- y), while quarterly earnings increased \(16.0\%\) y- y to CNY6.5bn (1H25 earnings growth of \(15.6\%\) y- y). Thanks to Haier's continued efforts to reduce costs/improve efficiency in the domestic market, along with its premium product positioning/integration of supply chain in the overseas markets, the company delivered a 1H25 gross margin of \(26.9\%\) (up 0.1pp y- y). Haier has further optimized its operations through digitalization, leading to a 0.1pp y- y improvement in its sales- cost ratio in 1H25 to \(10.1\%\) . Furthermore, Haier announced an interim DPS of CNY0.269, the first interim dividend of the company, indicating its strong commitment to shareholder returns, in our view. Haier's current FY25F dividend yield stands at a decent level of \(4.7\%\) .
Longfor Group Holdings (960 HK) (Neutral) - Weak 1H25 results with gloomy outlook (TP HKD 9.50- - HKD 10.70) Jizhou Dong, CFA - NIHK / Riley Jin - NIHK
Weak 1H25 results on DP margin miss; maintain Neutral

Weak 1H25 results; gross margin likely to stay under pressure in 2H25F. Longfor reported weak 1H25 results (29 Aug); interim revenue increased \(25\%\) y- y to CNY58.8bn, mainly driven by more development property (DP) revenue recognition (CNY45.5bn, up \(35\%\) y- y). However, core net profit dropped by c. \(70\%\) y- y to CNY1.4bn in 1H25, largely in line with its profit warning, as DP profitability further deteriorated (1H25 GPM: \(0.2\%\) , - 7.2pp y- y). On a positive note, Longfor's leverage continued to improve; interest- bearing debt reduced by CNY6.5bn h- h and average financing cost fell to a historical low of \(3.58\%\) . Looking ahead, we expect the gross margin of Longfor's property sales segment to remain under pressure due to the low margin profile of unbooked pre- sales. For FY25F, we now forecast a slightly negative DP gross margin and anticipate more impairments, thus cutting our core earnings forecast to CNY3.1bn (- \(56\%\) y- y).
Midea Group (000333 CH) (Buy) - Strong performance reinforces sector leadership (TP CNY 96.70- - CNY 98.00) Jizhou Dong, CFA - NIHK / Riley Jin - NIHK
Solid sales and earnings growth in 2Q25; momentum to continue in 2H25F; reiterate Buy

A strong 2Q25; sales/earnings to retain momentum in 2H25F. Midea announced its 2Q25 results (29 Aug) with another set of solid numbers. Quarterly revenue increased by \(11\%\) y- y to CNY124bn (1H25 revenue up \(16\%\) y- y to CNY252bn, the fastest among the three major Chinese white goods players we cover), while quarterly core earnings increased \(23\%\) y- y to CNY13.5bn (1H25 core earnings up a strong \(30\%\) y- y to CNY26.2bn, notably outpacing major peers). The faster growth of earnings than revenue in 1H25 was mainly driven by: 1) the 0.8pp y- y improvement in Midea's operating margin thanks to its cost- saving efforts (despite a 0.7pp y- y decline in the interim gross margin), and 2) contribution from financial income in 1H25. Midea also declared an interim dividend of
CNY0.5 per share; together with Midea's share repurchase plan (CNY4.4bn quota already used), we see the company's continued commitment to shareholder returns.
Ningbo Tuopu Group (601689 CH) (Buy) - Liquid cooling opens a new chapter of growth (TP CNY 55.00- →CNY 75.00)
Frank Fan - NIHK / Donnie Teng - NIHK / Joel Ying, CFA - NIHK

1H25 EPS softened due to key client's lackluster demand; liquid cooling and robotics to support long- term EPS growth 1H25 EPS declined y- y due to key client's lackluster shipments. Tuopu reported 1H25 results on 28 Aug after market close and hosted an investor and analyst meeting on 29 Aug. 1H25 revenue increased \(6\%\) y- y to CNY12,935mn, \(2\%\) higher than our estimate, mainly supported by \(+52\% /22\% /12\%\) y- y sales growth of electronics, electric drive system, and interior. 1H25 EPS declined \(11\%\) y- y to CNY1,295mn, \(5\%\) higher than our estimate, which was mainly caused by a 1.8bp gross margin decline to \(19.6\%\) due to increased depreciation and an increase in its opex ratio to \(9.4\%\) (vs \(8.1\%\) in 1H24) on growing R&D investments. Domestic OEMs growth could offset key client shipment decline; liquid cooling and robotics support EPS long- term growth. For 2H25 outlook, 1) we think the growing demand from domestic OEMs such as Xiaomi (1810 HK, Neutral), which are poised to sustain robust shipment growth, could offset the lackluster volume shipments of Tuopu's key client.
Shennan Circuits (002916 CH) (Buy) - 2Q25: strong AI PCB demand driving earnings uptick... (TP CNY 116.15- →CNY 220.00)
Bing Duan - NIHK / Anne Lee, CFA - NITB

Action: Maintain Buy but raise TP to CNY220, implying \(18\%\) upside. Shennan Circuits (SC) reported strong 2Q25 results on 26 August after market close, with revenue / earnings recording \(30\% /43\%\) y- y growth, beating our estimates by \(11\% /63\%\) on stronger PCB shipments and margin expansion. As one of the leading AI PCB/IC substrate suppliers in China, we think SC is a key beneficiary of China's AI chip development, led by its long- term partnership with top AI/tech customers, i.e., Huawei (unlisted) and Cambricon (688256 CH, Not rated). Meanwhile, SC is making solid progress in the global AI PCB market, as overseas market growth accelerated to \(47\%\) y- y (vs \(29\%\) y- y in FY24) and contributed \(37\%\) of total revenue in 1H25. In view of the robust demand for AIPCB and IC substrate (primarily for China customers), we raise FY25- 27F revenue and earnings forecasts by \(3.5 - 12\%\) and \(13.2 - 29.3\%\) , respectively.
Wuxi Lead Intelligent Equipment (300450 CH) (Buy) - ASSB equipment as a new growth driver (Neutral- →Buy, TP CNY 16.00- →CNY 41.00)
Ethan Zhang - NIHK / Frank Fan - NIHK

2Q25: sequential improvement due to better domestic battery demand. Wuxi Lead Intelligent (Lead) reported its 1H25 results with revenue up \(15\%\) y- y to CNY6.6bn (2Q25: \(+44\%\) y- y or \(13\%\) q- q), which we attribute to a recovery in domestic battery equipment demand. Battery equipment revenue grew \(16\%\) y- y to CNY4.5bn in 1H25, contributing \(69\%\) to the total revenue. GPM contracted by 2.5pp y- y to \(33.8\%\) in 1H (2Q25: down 2.6pp y- y or 1.5pp q- q to \(33.1\%\) ), likely owing to a shift in the revenue mix with increased contribution from low- margin domestic orders during 2023- 24. With effective cost control, the company's opex ratio improved by 3.0pp y- y to \(24.5\%\) in 1H. Lead reported a \(61\%\) y- y earnings growth to CNY740mn, translating into a 2Q25 earnings of CNY375mn (vs net loss of CNY105mn in 2Q24, or \(+3\%\) q- q growth). ASSB order momentum likely to continue in 2H25- FY26F.
Zhejiang Sanhua Intelligent (002050 CH) (Buy) - Unlocking new revenue streams via liquid cooling (Neutral- →Buy, TP CNY 30.00- →CNY 37.00)
Frank Fan - NIHK / Donnie Teng - NIHK
Solid 1H25 backed by refrigeration; liquid cooling likely to support long- term EPS growth; upgrade to Buy

Solid 1H25 EPS growth supported by refrigeration business. Sanhua reported 1H25 results on 28 Aug after market close and hosted an investor and analyst meeting on 29 Aug. 1H25 revenue increased \(19\%\) y- y to CNY16,263mn, which was mainly supported by \(+25\%\) y- y sales growth in refrigeration supported by subsidy program in China and growing penetration in the overseas market, offset by a slower \(9\%\) y- y growth in the auto component business due to key client's lackluster shipment. 1H25 earnings increased \(39\%\) y- y to CNY2,110mn, which was driven by a 0.7bps y- y improvement in gross margin at \(28.1\%\) , and a decline in opex ratio to \(12.4\%\) (vs \(13.9\%\) in 1H24), supported by management's operating efficiency initiatives. A mixed bag for 2H25F outlook; liquid cooling likely to support long- term refrigeration sales growth.
Hangzhou Robam (002508 CH) (Neutral) - 1H25 results in line (TP CNY 19.90- →CNY 20.30)
Jizhou Dong, CFA - NIHK / Riley Jin - NIHK

1H25 results in line, likely moderate sales recovery in 3Q25F off a low base; maintain Neutral 1H25 results in- line, with revenue miss and margin beat. Robam's announced 1H25 results on 29 Aug, were broadly in line with the capital market's expectations. Interim revenue decreased \(2.6\%\) y- y to CNY4.61bn in 1H25, and net margin dropped 0.6pp y- y to \(15.4\%\) , leading to a \(6.3\%\) y- y decline in interim earnings to CNY710mn. While Robam's revenue fell short of our expectations for 1H25F, the company's improved efficiency, through better supply chain management and tighter cost control, helped offset the topline weakness and reduced expense ratios, resulting in a better- than- expected operating margin/net margin of \(17.4\% /14.7\%\) (up 0.5/0.2pp y- y) in 2Q25. By product category, we noted traditional stove and hood sales underperformed due to intensifying competition, while dishwashers, still at a low penetration rate, delivered strong growth with the help of government subsidies.
Oppein Home Group (603833 CH) (Neutral) - Weak 1H25 results (TP CNY 69.20- →CNY 53.00)
Jizhou Dong, CFA - NIHK / Riley Jin - NIHK

Weak 1H25 results; await property sector recovery. Oppen Home Group reported a set of weak 1H25 results on 29 Aug, below our expectations. In 1H25, the company delivered revenue of CNY8.24bn, down \(4.0\%\) y- y, with attributable net profit of CNY1.02bn, up \(2.9\%\) y- y. We believe the slower- than- expected sales performance reflects sluggish home furnishing demand and limited progress from channel transformation; in detail: (1) the government trade- in subsidies provided little uplift for Oppen, with most categories declining again off a low base; (2) although the net reduction of stores narrowed in 1H25 compared with 2024, closures still weighed on revenue. On a positive note, profitability was supported by an improved channel mix and tighter cost control, offsetting impact from weaker investment income, leading to a 0.8pp y- y improvement in net margin to \(12.4\%\) .
Quick Note - United Imaging (688271 CH) (Neutral) - 2Q25 results: growth picked up (TP CNY 139.75) Jialin Zhang, CFA, CPA - NIHK

Sales and recurring earnings up \(18 / 18\%\) y- y in 2Q25. United Imaging reported 1H25 results on 29 Aug after market close: sales/earnings rose \(12.8\% /5.0\%\) y- y to CNY6.02bn/CNY998mn. This suggests 2Q25 revenue increased \(18.6\%\) y- y to CNY3.54bn (beat Bloomberg consensus by \(4.7\%\) ) and earnings came in at CNY628mn \((+7.0\%)\) y- y, \(6.2\%\) higher than the Bloomberg consensus estimate). The topline beat, in our view, was due to: (1) better- than- expected domestic sales growth led by market share gains and (2) continued overseas expansion. By geography, domestic revenue rose \(11\%\) y- y to CNY4.9bn in 1H25, and overseas revenue grew \(22\%\) y- y to CNY1.1bn in the same period. Segment- wise, in 1H25: 1) equipment sales edged up \(7.6\%\) y- y to CNY4.89bn, on the back of a rebound in MR/MI sales to CNY1.97bn/CNY841mn, equivalent to \(16.8\% /13.2\%\) y- y growth, offsetting soft CT sales (- \(6.4\%\) y- y to CNY1.52bn), and 2) the after- sales business achieved revenue of CNY816mn \((+32.2\%)\) y- y), on the back of enhanced value- added services and customer loyalty.
Quick Note - Atter Energy (ATHERENE IN) (Buy) - Atter unveils EL platform, connected mobility (TP INR 458)
Kapil Singh - NFASL / Siddhartha Bera, CFA - NFASL

Atter, on 30 August 2025, unveiled EL, its next- generation scooter platform, along with AtterStack 7.0, the Redux concept, Infinite Cruise, a new 6 kW fast- charger generation, and OTA updates for the Rizta range, alongside Halo helmet updates and expanded vehicle security/remote- control features at the third edition of its Atter Community Day 2025. The EL platform marks Atter's first new vehicle architecture since the Atter 450. The platform introduces a new chassis, powertrain and electronics stack, while its simplified design reduces component count to enable \(15\%\) faster assembly and up to 2x faster servicing, extending service intervals to \(10\mathrm{km}\) , with manufacturing for new models (first in the festival season of 2026) to be carried out at Atter's new Aurangabad (Chhatrapati Sambhajinagar) facility. The EL platform supports multiple form factors and battery packs ranging from \(2.2 - 5.0\mathrm{kWh}\) .
Samvardhana Motherson International (MOTHERSO IN) (Buy) - Yutaka acquisition at very attractive valuation (TP INR 116) Kapil Singh - NFASL / Siddhartha Bera, CFA - NFASL

SAMIL, on 29 August 2025, announced the acquisition of an \(81\%\) stake in Yutaka Giken Co Ltd (YGCL; 7229 JP, Not rated), a listed Japanese automotive components company, alongside an \(100\%\) stake in Yutaka Autoparts India Pvt Ltd (unlisted) and a \(11\%\) stake in Shinnichi Kogyo Co Ltd (unlisted) from Honda Motor (7267 JP, Not rated). The deal will be executed via SAMIL's wholly- owned subsidiary, Motherson Global Investments BV. The transaction will close in multiple stages (tender offer, squeeze- out, buyback), with completion targeted by 1QFY27E, subject to merger control approvals in Japan, US, China, Brazil, and Mexico. Business overview and strategic fit: YGCL, incorporated in 1954, manufactures braking systems, rotors and stator assemblies for motors, and thermal management systems, supplying primarily to Honda Motor. Its FY25 turnover was JPY179bn (\~USD1.2bn), with operations across 13 manufacturing facilities and one R&D center in nine countries.
Quick Note - Zydus Lifesciences (ZYDUSLIF IN) (Buy) - Saroglitazar for PBC: Positive clinical data (TP INR 1,140) Saison Mukherjee - NFASL / Amlan Jyoti Das - NFASL / Kushal Chovatia - NFASL

Positive clinical end point in Saroglitazar registration trials for PBC; the company now intends to submit NDA in 1Q 2026. Zydus Lifesciences on 29 August 2025 announced positive results from the Phase 2b/3 registration trials of Saroglitazar for PBC (Primary Biliary Cholangitis). The EPICS- III trials evaluated the safety and efficacy of Saroglitazar in treating adult patients with PBC, that are not adequately responding or are intolerant to the first- line medication ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA). The trial has met the primary end point and achieved a defined biochemical response. In the clinical trial Saroglitazar, 1mg was administered once daily. We note that in the earlier phases of clinical trials, higher dosages of Saroglitazar, i.e., 2mg and 4mg once daily were also considered. However, Saroglitazar achieved the desired clinical outcome at a lower dose.
Quick Note - Zydus Lifesciences (ZYDUSLIF IN) (Buy) - Comfort Click acquisition (TP INR 1,140)
Saison Mukherjee - NFASL / Amlan Jyoti Das - NFASL / Kushal Chovatia - NFASL

Zydus acquires Comfort Click to foray into VMS in the UK and Europe. Zydus Lifesciences' subsidiary, Zydus Wellness, announced on 29 August 2025 the acquisition of \(100\%\) stake in Comfort Click Limited (unlisted), a UK based digital consumer healthcare platform for a consideration of GBP239mn. The company primarily has a presence in the Vitamins, Minerals and Supplements (VMS) segment. Comfort Click has a presence in \(\sim 13\) countries, with operations across the UK and Europe. It plans to expand into the US in the near term, according to the company. The company caters to adult, paediatric and animal health segments, with a diversified product portfolio consisting of three major brands - WeightWorld, Maxmedix and Animigo.

WeightWorld includes plant- based supplements, vitamins and minerals, collagen, omegas, probiotics and micronutrients and sports nutrition for adults. Maxmedix is a specialty VMS gummy brand catering to paediatric nutritional requirements.
Mihir P. Shah - NFASL / Riya Patni - NFASL
Positives: Copra down m-m, tea, sorbitol soften; Brent, wheat still down y-y; Negatives: Amla rise continues; palm oil again inflationary; key beneficiaries: BRIT, TATACONS

Raw material price movements - August 2025. Prices of most commodities are still soft q-q and will likely support GPM improvement in 2Q and 3QFY26F. However, RM prices have started to inch up m-m. While companies will have lower- priced RM inventory, we believe that if prices continue to rise, then product price hikes could make a comeback in 4Q (which are negligible currently). We believe the demand environment is conducive and is showing signs of improvement; also, with overall inflation being low, we do not expect consumer companies to take a hit on their margins this time. For August, the notable trends are - (1) Copra finally began its downtrend after seeing \(100\% +\) y- y rise; tea prices have also moderated; this will aid in easing/improving margins for MRCO/TATACONS, in our view. (2) Palm oil turned inflationary after July and the price has continued to rise in August.
CIMB Group (CIMB MK) (Buy) - Cost control, NOII offset IDR depreciation impact (TP MYR 8.90- MYR 8.80)
Tushar Mohata, CFA - NSM / Alpa Aggarwal, CFA - NSFSPL

2Q25 results slightly below, mainly due to IDR's depreciation vs MYR:CIMB's 2Q25 adjusted NPATAM at MYR1.9bn was down \(4\%\) y- y and q-q, with 1H25 NPATAMI forming \(49\%\) of both our previous and Bloomberg consensus estimates. The slight miss was because of CIMB's outsized Indonesia exposure (vs other Malaysian banking peers) and the sharp depreciation of IDR vs MYR (- \(9\%\) y- y) affecting earnings, but underlying constant currency performance was in- line. Apart from this, there was a slight NIM compression (- 1bp q-q) and higher provisions, but good cost control and non- interest income performance offset these. CIMB announced an interim dividend of 19.75sen/ share (vs 20sen/share and special dividend of 7sen/share in 1H24) and indicated that \(55.5\%\) payout will form the floor; we see opportunity for higher payout, provided earnings/capital in 2H25F are supportive.
Inari Amerton (INRI MK) (Buy) - New projects could finally gain traction (Neutral- Buy, TP MYR 2.36- MYR 2.44) Heng Siong Kong - NSM / Aakash Kedia - NSFSPL

4QFY25 review: Lower volume loadings across all segments dampened topline. Inari hosted an earnings call earlier today following the announcement of its 4QFY25 results on 28 August 2025 (note). Management highlighted that FY25 was generally weaker y- y due to lower volume loadings in all business segments and less favorable forex (weaker average USD vs MYR). Profitability margins were also affected by its loss- making operations in Yiwu, China, which is averaging a MYR5mn loss per quarter. RF ramp- up ongoing; losses in memory and China might narrow on higher volume. Under its radio frequency (RF) segment, Inari is in the midst of ramping up production for upcoming launches of new iPhone models in Sept 2025. It has also started developing some new programs for 2026 models. According to management, the memory division's current run- rate is \(\sim 24k / day\) and the unit is still loss- making. To address this, it aims to reach 40k/day upon material normalization from its customer.
Ahmad Maghfur Usman - NSM / Shashwat Choudhary - NSFSPL

TNB reported a core net profit (adjusted to exclude MFRS- 16 impact) of MYR1bn (- 32% y- y, - 14% q- q). The decrease in earnings was attributed to a combination of higher overall opex (- 7% y- y, +5% q- q), higher depreciation (+4% y- y, +4% q- q), higher fuel costs and lower contribution from JV and associates (- 94% y- y, - 22% q- q). 1HFY25 core net profit was down 14% y- y at MYR2.2bn. The earnings delivered accounted for 35% of our full- year forecast, which we deem a miss (slight miss on Bloomberg consensus at 47%). 2QFY25 EBITDA was MYR4.1bn (- 2% y- y, - 3% q- q), with 1HFY25 EBITDA being a miss on our FY25E forecast at 45%. However, barring the huge miss on the JV and associates share contribution (due to our FY25E forecasts being significantly high at MYR400mn), we think the shortfall would be made up for in 2HFY25E on the back of the recent revision in the scheduled tariff across the board (refer to link), lower opex (typically frontloaded) and the strengthening of MYR against the USD (which would lower finance costs).
Ahmad Maghfur Usman - NSM / Mishu Agarwal - NSFSPL

2Q25 review. CAPITAL A on 28 August 2025 reported the results of two distinct businesses - aviation and non- aviation. The aviation segment reported a core PATAMI of MYR170mn in 2Q25 (vs a core loss of MYR32mn in 1Q25). 1H25 revenue declined by \(2\%\) y- y while core profit came in at MYR138mn (vs a loss of 706mn in 1H24), which was a miss and formed only \(32\%\) of our full- year estimate for FY25F. The number of passengers in 2Q25 declined by \(4\%\) q- q and - 0.7% y- y to 15.53mn due to softness in Thailand, which we believe will likely persist into the ensuing quarters largely due to weaker tourism and safety concerns there. As a result, aviation and ancillary revenue of MYR4,471mn overall came in weaker (- 3% y- y, - 9% q- q). Capacity expansion was flattish q- q and grew by \(8.5\%\) y- y, and passenger load factor (PLF) came in at \(82\%\) (- 4pp q- q). The aviation segment was supported by lower fuel prices (- 15% y- y) as global fuel price softened.
Quick Note - IHH Healthcare (IHH MK) (Neutral) - Underwhelming 2Q25 on weak SG, payor pressure (TP MYR 7.20) Raghavendra Divekar, CFA - NSM

2Q25 results below expectations on weaker Singapore business, payor pressure. IHH reported 2Q25 results, with overall revenue up \(3\%\) y- y, but coming in \(4\%\) below our forecast, as shown in Fig. 1. Revenue growth was mixed across markets, with strong performance in Malaysia on the back of acquisitions, but challenges in other regions including Singapore which was impacted by the renovation of Mount Elizabeth hospital. Operating costs were roughly flat y- y, although staff cost as a share of revenue rose 1.1pp y- y and came in line with our expectation. The company's PATMI of MYR443mn showed a \(29\%\) y- y decline coming in \(17\%\) below our expectation, while PATMI, excluding exceptional items and the impact of MFRS129, was MYR518m, down \(9\%\) y- y and \(3\%\) below our forecast and below consensus. Key exceptional items included: (1) an MYR15mn gain from exchange difference on net borrowings; and (2) a MYR15mn net monetary gain from a hyperinflationary economy.
Telekom Malaysia (T MK) (Neutral) - 2Q25: Subscribers stable as ARPUs took a dent (Buy \(\rightarrow\) Neutral, TP MYR 7.88 \(\rightarrow\) MYR 7.85)
Heng Siong Kong - NSM / Aakash Kedia - NSFSPL
Market competition puts pressure on ARPUs; downgrade to Neutral, with TP cut to MYR7.85

Subscribers appear resilient, ARPUs under pressure amidst heightened competition. Telekom Malaysia (TM) posted 1HFY25 EBITDA of MYR2.2bn, accounting for \(44\% /48\%\) of ourBloomberg consensus full- year estimates, which we deem slightly below expectations. 2Q25 revenue at MYR2.77bn was down \(3\%\) q- q/ \(5\%\) y- y. 2Q25 EBITDA at MYR1.1bn was up \(4\%\) q- q but down \(1\%\) y- y. TM's core profit of MYR403mn for 2Q was flat q- q and up \(2\%\) y- y. TM declared an interim dividend of MYR0.125 per share. Key takeaways from the earnings call. Unifi's (unlisted, B2C) 2Q25 revenue at MYR1.38bn was down \(1\%\) q- q and y- y. Its subscriber base increased marginally (up \(0.1\%\) q- q and up \(1.4\%\) y- y) to 3.2mn, while ARPU dropped to MYR125 (MYR128 in 2Q24 and MYR127 in 1Q25). According to management, given the intensifying competition in the industry, TM rolled out promotional discounts to retain subscribers and to match the aggressive competition.
Raghavendra Divekar, CFA - NSM / Kriti Agrawal - NSFSPL
Commodity prices still trending downwards; companies with strong brands see SSSG growth in 2Q25

Commodity prices take a pause but still down y- y - positive for consumer margins. Commodity prices have been largely trending down since the start of 2025 after their strong performance in 2024, but some of them recorded a pause in August. Lower prices for cocoa and stable prices for sugar should benefit F&B companies in Malaysia by lowering production costs. Major Malaysian F&B companies include Farm Fresh (FFB MK, Buy), Nestle Malaysia (NESZ MK, Not rated), F&N (FNH MK, Not rated) and Apollo Food (APOF MK, Not rated). We believe the continued decline in wheat and corn prices on a y- y basis should reduce input costs for companies such as QL Resources (QLG MK, Buy) and Farm Fresh. WMP prices have started to increase, but we think Farm Fresh's margins would be protected as it has adequate supply through Dec- 2025 and plans to lower its dependence on whole milk powder (WMP) for milk from \(50\%\) to \(25 - 30\%\) going forward.
Silergy (6415 TT) (Buy) - All eyes on execution (TP TWD 535.00- TWD 430.00)
Aaron Jeng, CFA - NITB / Donnie Teng - NIHK / Eric Chen, CFA - NITB / Vivian Yang - NITB
Management finally tones down 2025E, clearing path for 2026E rebound with pipeline conversion

Reiterate Buy on reset expectations, but cut TP to TWD430. Silergy's 2Q25 GM missed our estimates due to a one- off supply disruption, despite stable pricing conditions, and management expects a normalization in 2H25E. Silergy finally admitted to 2025E revenue falling short of its \(20 - 30\%\) y- y growth target (in USD terms; we have flagged below- guidance growth since January), but attributed the weakness to its higher North American "end- customer" exposure in the consumer and computing verticals whose production plans are affected by tariff policy uncertainty. Although China demand market commentary sounds more encouraging, we are skeptical about Silergy's execution to "recoup share in the consumer end- market", as its Chinese competitors have broadly reported solid revenue growth with demand strength across the board.

From the perspective of obtaining fairness and transparency in the market, registration system for credit rating agencies has been introduced based on amended Financial Instruments and Exchange Act.

In accordance with this, those financial instruments business operators utilizing ratings assigned by unregistered rating agencies ("Unregistered Ratings") upon soliciting clients are obligated to notify their clients that these ratings are Unregistered Ratings and to provide them with such other information necessary as the significance of registration.

Those credit rating agencies which have been registered under the system will be supervised by the Financial Services Agency (FSA) and will be subject to certain restrictions. Such restrictions include the following: duty of candor and good faith; obligation to maintain compliance system to prevent conflict of interest and to maintain fairness in the credit rating process; prohibited from assigning ratings on those securities which they are holders of; and obligation to prepare and disclose rating policies and other necessary documents and to make publicly available the explanation materials and other necessary documents.
They will also be obligated to report to FSA upon its request, to accept on- site investigations, to receive business improvement order and will be under other forms of supervision by FSA.
Unregistered rating agencies will not be subject to these restrictions and supervision by FSA.

Investors in the financial products offered by Nomura Securities may incur fees and commissions specific to those products (for example, transactions involving Japanese equities are subject to a sales commission (all figures on a tax- inclusive basis) of up to \(1.43\%\) of the transaction amount or a commission of \(2,860 for transactions of\) 200,000 or less, while transactions involving investment trusts are subject to various fees, such as commissions at the time of purchase and asset management fees, such as commissions at the time of purchase and asset management fees (trust fees), specific to each investment trust).

In addition, all products carry the risk of losses owing to price fluctuations or other factors. Fees and risks vary by product. Please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract, listed securities documents, or prospectuses.

Transactions involving Japanese equities (including Japanese REITs, Japanese ETFs, and Japanese ETNs, Japanese Infrastructure Funds) are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.43\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(2,860 (tax included) for transactions of\) 200,000 or less). When Japanese equities are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Japanese equities carry the risk of losses owing to price fluctuations. Japanese REITs carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in price and/or earnings of underlying real estate. Japanese ETFs and ETNs carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in the underlying indexes or other benchmarks. Japanese Infrastructure Funds carry out the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in price and/or earnings of underlying infrastructures.

Transactions involving foreign equities are subject to a domestic sales commission of up to \(1.045\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (which equals the local transaction amount plus local fees and taxes in the case of a purchase or the local transaction amount minus local fees and taxes in the case of a sale) (for transaction amounts of \(750,000 and below, maximum domestic sales commission is\) 7,810 (tax included)). Local fees and taxes in foreign financial instruments markets vary by country/territory. When foreign equities are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Foreign equities carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as price fluctuations and foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

Margin transactions are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.43\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(2,860 (tax included) for transactions of\) 200,000 or less), as well as management fees and rights handling fees. In addition, long margin transactions are subject to interest on the purchase amount, while short margin transactions are subject to fees for the lending of the shares borrowed. A margin equal to at least \(30\%\) of the transaction amount (at least \(33\%\) for online transactions) and at least \(300,000 is required. With margin transactions, an amount up to roughly 3.3x the margin (roughly 3x for online transactions) may be traded. Margin transactions therefore carry the risk of losses in excess of the margin owing to share price fluctuations. For details, please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as listed securities documents or documents delivered before making a contract.

Transactions involving convertible bonds are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.10\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(4,400 (tax included) if this would be less than\) 4,400). When convertible bonds are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Convertible bonds carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as interest rate fluctuations and price fluctuations in the underlying stock. In addition, convertible bonds denominated in foreign currencies also carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

When bonds are purchased via public offerings, secondary distributions, or other OTC transactions with Nomura Securities, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. Bonds carry the risk of losses, as prices fluctuate in line with changes in market interest rates. Bond prices may also fall below the invested principal as a result of such factors as changes in the management and financial circumstances of the issuer, or changes in third- party valuations of the bond in question. In addition, foreign currency- denominated bonds also carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

When Japanese government bonds (JGBs) for individual investors are purchased via public offerings, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. As a rule, JGBs for individual investors may not be sold in the first 12 months after issuance. When JGBs for individual investors are sold before maturity, an amount calculated via the following formula will be subtracted from the par value of the bond plus accrued interest: (1) for 10- year variable rate bonds, an amount equal to the two preceding coupon payments (before tax) x 0.79685 will be used, (2) for 5- year and 3- year fixed rate bonds, an amount equal to the two preceding coupon payments (before tax) x 0.79685 will be used.

When inflation- indexed JGBs are purchased via public offerings, secondary distributions (uridashi deals), or other OTC transactions with Nomura Securities, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. Inflation- indexed JGBs carry the risk of losses, as prices fluctuate in line with changes in market interest rates and fluctuations in the nationwide consumer price index. The notional principal of inflation- indexed JGBs changes in line with the rate of change in nationwide CPI inflation from the time of its issuance. The amount of the coupon payment is calculated by multiplying the coupon rate by the notional principal at the time of payment. The maturity value is the amount of the notional principal when the issue becomes due. For J117 and subsequent issues, the maturity value shall not undercut the face amount.

Purchases of investment trusts (and sales of some investment trusts) are subject to a purchase or sales fee of up to \(5.5\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount. Also, a direct cost that may be incurred when selling investment trusts is a fee of up to \(2.0\%\) of the unit price at the time of redemption. Indirect costs that may be incurred during the course of holding investment trusts include, for domestic investment trusts, an asset management fee (trust fee) of up to \(5.5\%\) (tax included/annualized basis) of the net assets in trust, as well as fees based on investment performance. Other indirect costs may also be incurred. For foreign investment trusts, indirect fees may be incurred during the course of holding such as investment company compensation.

Investment trusts invest mainly in securities such as Japanese and foreign equities and bonds, whose prices fluctuate. Investment trust unit prices fluctuate owing to price fluctuations in the underlying assets and to foreign exchange rate fluctuations. As such, investment trusts carry the risk of losses. Fees and risks vary by investment trust. Maximum applicable fees are subject to change; please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as prospectuses or documents delivered before making a contract.
In interest rate swap transactions and USD/JPY basis swap transactions ("interest rate swap transactions, etc."), only the agreed transaction

payments shall be made on the settlement dates. Some interest rate swap transactions, etc. may require pledging of margin collateral. In some of these cases, transaction payments may exceed the amount of collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the transaction. Interest rate swap transactions, etc. carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in market prices in the interest rate, currency and other markets, as well as reference indices. Losses incurred as such may exceed the value of margin collateral, in which case margin calls may be triggered. In the event that both parties agree to enter a replacement (or termination) transaction, the interest rates received (paid) under the new arrangement may differ from those in the original arrangement, even if terms other than the interest rates are identical to those in the original transaction. Risks vary by transaction. Please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract and disclosure statements.

In OTC transactions of credit default swaps (CDS), no sales commission will be charged. When entering into CDS transactions, the protection buyer will be required to pledge or entrust an agreed amount of margin collateral. In some of these cases, the transaction payments may exceed the amount of margin collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the financial position of the protection buyer. CDS transactions carry the risk of losses owing to changes in the credit position of some or all of the referenced entities, and/or fluctuations of the interest rate market. The amount the protection buyer receives in the event that the CDS is triggered by a credit event may undercut the total amount of premiums that he/she has paid in the course of the transaction. Similarly, the amount the protection seller pays in the event of a credit event may exceed the total amount of premiums that he/she has received in the transaction. All other conditions being equal, the amount of premiums that the protection buyer pays and that received by the protection seller shall differ. In principle, CDS transactions will be limited to financial instruments business operators and qualified institutional investors.

Transfers of equities to another securities company via the Japan Securities Depository Center are subject to a transfer fee of up to 11,000 (tax included) per issue transferred depending on volume. No account fee will be charged for marketable securities or monies deposited.
